TopicTitle: [IMPORTANT RESEARCH - PLEASE HELP]. Figuring the average LKO altitude.

Articles.Content:
From 80 to 110km for low tier satellites and probes (and mostly debris).

From 110 to 190km for shuttles and others experimental stuff.

From 190 to 210km for Space Stations.

From 210 to 2000km for high tier satellites.

This is only for Kerbin, I have other rules for different planets.

All orbits are almost perfectly circular. I don't care if debris aren't in a circular orbit.
100 km orbit
Pretty much always 71 km. Not sure why you would go past 75 if you're just doing transfers (which I know a lot of people aren't).
Anywhere from 80km x 80km up to 200km x 200km for transfer parking orbits. I put stations at 400km x 400km.
I usually park at 80 km. That or 100 km.

Usually 100km x 100km.

Current save:

80km: Munar shuttle refueling station

90km: A satellite

100km: The debris of 20+ launches, two space stations <<< 100km is my usual launch orbit for pretty much everything, including anything that will go higher

150km: Another satellite

2868km: 3 satellites and a Jebediah Kerman* <<< Synchronous Orbit *directly above KSC

84000km: "How slow can I go in an orbit around Kerbin" probe
100 KM for most things, 125 for interplanetary things. I will go to 600 KM if i have to warp at 10000x for some reason.
125 KM for almost anything.

I send most stuff anywhere 75-90km. My station is at 120km. I consider anything inside kerbin-stationary orbit to be LKO. (even though I do not know exactly where that is)

EDIT: My refueling stations go to 100km.

I put most craft into orbit at around 80-100km to start. Stations I usually park at 150-300, satellites at either 500km or Geosynchronous. If I'm building in orbit, I place the core module at 150km and other parts at 80 to set up for transfer.

100KM because it is rounded number

120KM for stations

[closed]

Edited July 4, 2021 by benjiful9000

Generally 125 km if I have to do any rendezvous, since it makes the warp quicker if I don't get the window right. Stations usually go at 80 and 250 km. I generally build launch vehicles that are a bit overpowered for a simple 75-80km orbit anyways, so it's not usually a problem getting stuff up that high.

125 works good for manned missions unless they're extremely heavy, as it gives you the extra warp factor if you're transferring to the mun or minmus.

I go mostly for 90 km at launch and my station is parked at 100 km altitude... but I guess that even 100 km altitude is more than enough for a station. Real world ISS is orbiting at 420 km whereas the Earth's got just 10 times bigger equatorial radius... that would mean that you'd be in a same position above Kerbin when orbiting at 42 km altitude... so 100 km altitude is just enough for me
69500mx69500m if i can - milking that oberth effect for all it's worth.

Stations are 99 - 105 km. The SSTOs that I've built from scratch are like 80km, because I need enough dV to get home and my designs have enough to get to 80km.

My default is 100km.

100 km for most stuff.

125 km for interplanetary transfers.

Depends on destination,

If leaving Kerbin SOI, 80Km

if testing/maneuvering/intercepts in LKO 100Km

satellites are generally over 125Km

Edited August 9, 2013 by Nexustrimean
75-80km is a good parking orbit if you're going to other planets.

It was always 100km for me in 0.20. But at the moment I'm doing a program similar to the campaign on the Wiki, and I've started doing 69km for satellites to help reduce space debris. The satellites own thrusters push it above 70km after that
My minimum orbit cap is 95 km. I like to hit at least 105, however.

Depends on destination,

If leaving Kerbin SOI, 80Km

if testing/maneuvering/intercepts in LKO 100Km

same here, plus space stations at 400km.

I bumped my station orbit to 125~130km primarily to be within the elevation that will give me 50x time warp . . . I can be infinitely patient when actually flying, rendezvous, docking, but I hate just waiting for my stuff to finish crawling around from the backside of the planet . . .

I put my LKO refueling stations at 125, I usually do orbital assembly for interplanetary craft a bit lower (for easy transfers), my standard LKO for satellites and non-rendezvous stuff is usually 80-105, and lastly, my interplanetary transfer parking orbit is typically 75.

~74 if its a craft with standard TWR for transfer

~85 for more difficult crafts (low TWR LV-N stage)

<70 for performance flights.

If you want to pick one for research go with 74
